conclusion: To find the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we need to use Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction.
The induced EMF in a rotating coil in a uniform magnetic field can be described by the formula: \( \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \).
Where: \( n \) is the number of turns of the coil, \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity, \( A \) is the area of the coil, \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, \( t \) is the time.

Since the problem asks for the magnitude of the induced EMF and does not specify a particular time \( t \), we will consider the maximum value of the induced EMF, which occurs when \( \sin(\omega t) = 1 \).

premise: The maximum induced EMF is given by: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = n B A \omega \).
conclusion: The maximum induced EMF is \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = n B A \omega \).

premise: The side lengths are \( l_{AB}=0.2\mathrm{m} \) and \( l_{BC}=0.5\mathrm{m} \).
conclusion: The area \( A \) of the rectangular coil is \( A = l_{AB} \times l_{BC} = 0.2 \, \text{m} \times 0.5 \, \text{m} = 0.1 \, \text{m}^2 \).

premise: Substitute the given values into the formula for the maximum induced EMF: \( n = 100 \), \( B = 0.1 \, \text{T} \), \( A = 0.1 \, \text{m}^2 \), \( \omega = 100\pi \, \text{rad/s} \).

conclusion: The magnitude of the induced electromotive force in the coil is \( 314.16 \, \text{V} \).
